text: [Music]
despite the sweltering weather this
meeting held a touch of frost from the
start at the entrance to Frances
Versailles Palace the two leaders
greeted each other with brief handshakes
and small grim smiles two hours later
after their first meeting the mood was
if anything even cooler France and
Russia has backed different groups in
the Syrian conflict
mr. Makran said that while France did
not want to destabilize the Syrian state
there were red lines that must not be
crossed yes I stressed again in my
meeting with President Putin our firm
rejection and calm yes there is a very
clear red line that exists on our part
and that is the use of chemical weapons
by whoever it may be the use of chemical
weapons will be the object of immediate
retaliation on the part of the French
the two leaders are also divided over
the situation in Ukraine with the
Russian president condemning the
sanctions imposed on his country as a
result of the crisis a mobile deserves
fear the sanctions against Russia are
not helping to find a solution to the
crisis in Ukraine we must fight to lift
these economic restrictions this is the
only way we could be more free and be
able to restore peace in the region mr.
Putin also appeared to deny any Russian
interference in France's recent
presidential race despite allegations by
mr. macrons
team that Russian agents had tried
repeatedly to hack into their account
there's no son felices mr. micron
himself strongly defended the banning of
two Russian media outlets from covering
his campaign describing them as agents
of propaganda this choice of venue and
the inauguration of a new exhibition
here on 300 years of franco-russian tide
was meant to highlight the long
relationship between the two countries
but more recent events have made this a
stiff and awkward meeting and it showed
Lucy Williamson BBC News Versailles
